sec.div: Exploring responses across populations of the same species
sec.p: Due to their time-consuming nature, avian individual monitoring projects are often based on single study sites. However, the rare projects with comparisons across populations allow researchers to assess how generalizable single-population plasticity trends are (Porlier et al. 2012) but also to understand which factors drive differences in plasticity and evolution across a species range (Both et al. 2006). Since avian demographic responses to climate change are not uniform across species ranges (Jiguet et al. 2010) future studies should develop comparisons across the species thermal range. The study of populations at range-edge location may be of particular conservation value because they represent significant components of intraspecific biodiversity (Hardie and Hutchings 2010) and potential sources of evolutionary innovation and persistence during rapid environmental change such as global warming (Sexton et al. 2009).
